text.p: Air pollution is the world’s greatest environmental health threat, accounting for 7 million deaths around the world every year. Air pollution and climate change are closely linked through many common sources. Rapid progress to address air pollution can deliver tangible multiple-benefits and help the world community deliver on its commitments for climate, health and sustainable development.
The UNEP Pollution Dashboard displays the global state of air pollution, its impact on human health and major sources, and progress countries are making to tackle the challenge.

article.head: Nine out of ten people in the world are exposed to levels of air pollutants that exceed what the World Health Organization considers too high

text.p: Every breath you take, you suck in tiny particles that damage your lungs, heart, and brain causing a host of health problems. The most dangerous of these particles, which can be anything from soot to sulfates, are fine particles 2.5 microns or less in diameter —shortened as PM2.5.
Even though air pollution is a global problem, it disproportionately affects the world’s most vulnerable, often living in developing economies.

article.head: Residential pollution, mostly from cooking, heating and generating electricity for our homes, is the main human-made source of fine particles globally — although windblown dust is a major source in much of Africa and West Asia

text.p: Fine particles come from a wide range of sources, most of them from human activities like the burning of fossil fuels to generate electricity for homes and businesses and power, transportation, agriculture — a major source of methane and ammonia, and chemical and mining industries. Non-human sources are anything from volcanic eruptions, sea spray, and other natural processes.
Dirty indoor cooking and heating systems, for example, are a major problem in the developing world.

article.head: Around four million people died in 2019 from exposure to fine particulate air pollution, with the highest death rates occurring in Asia and Eastern Europe

text.p: Exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub> reduced average global life expectancy by approximately one year in 2016. It is a major global health epidemic, causing one in nine deaths worldwide.

The three biggest killers linked to PM<sub>2.5</sub> air pollution are stroke, heart disease, lung disease, and cancer. High levels of fine particles also contribute to other illnesses, like diabetes, and can also hinder cognitive development in children, and cause mental health problems.

Data for PM2.5 estimates, sectors and fuel sources, and attributable deaths comes from McDuffie, E.E., Martin, R.V., Spadaro, J.V. et al. Source sector and fuel contributions to ambient PM2.5 and attributable mortality across multiple spatial scales. Nat Commun 12, 3594 (2021)
The data for the sector and fuel sections was reaggregated from country data into UNEP regions —which are different from the ones used in the study.

Windblown dust, while a recognized source of PM<sub>2.5</sub> and health impacts in many parts of the world, was not included in the sector breakdown because it is primarily derived from natural sources.[f][g]
